Title: Religious Discrimination in Public Services
Abstract: Using large-scale field experiments, we explore the depth, breadth, and drivers of religious discrimination across various sectors in the United States.

Title: Backdoor Admissions? Socioeconomic Bias in College Recruiting
Abstract: Do the rich receive preferential treatment in college admissions? Is there still a back door that the affluent can use to get their foot into higher education? This project will audit college athletics departments to test whether families perceived as high-income receive preferential treatment in admissions-related communications compared to low-income families.

Title: Forever Foreign? Differential Linguistic Assimilation Standards for Asian Immigrants
Abstract: Do Americans hold immigrant groups to different assimilation standards? Using conjoint experiments with 2,999 Americans who evaluated which of 59,980 immigrant profiles was 'most assimilated,' we find that linguistic assimilation matters significantly more for Asian immigrants than for other groups.

Title: Measuring and Understanding Anti-Asian Bias in Immigration Preferences Worldwide
Abstract: How large is anti-Asian bias in public preferences over immigrants, how does it compare to other commonly studied attributes, and what drives these biases? We explore these questions using a large forced-choice conjoint experiment fielded in 22 democracies (N≈46,549).
